questions.text: Which of the following statements about EEG (Electroencephalogram) is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: EEG measures the summated version of EPSP and IPSP generated in the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: EEG records the dendritic potentials of pyramidal neurons.

options.label: C
options.text: Positive dendritic potentials are known as EPSP (Excitatory Postsynaptic Potential) and negative dendritic potentials are known as IPSP (Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential).

options.label: D
options.text: D) Electrocorticography (ECOG) is the measurement of electrical activity specifically in the cerebral cortex by placing electrodes on the surface of scalp.

questions.correct_answer: D. D) Electrocorticography (ECOG) is the measurement of electrical activity specifically in the cerebral cortex by placing electrodes on the surface of scalp.
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ EEG Function: Records electrical activity from the brain's surface, detecting dendritic potentials, not action potentials. EEG Components: Captures the summated EPSPs and IPSPs. Pyramidal Neurons: Major contributors to the signals detected by EEG.
  • ➤ EEG Function: Records electrical activity from the brain's surface, detecting dendritic potentials, not action potentials.
  • ➤ EEG Components: Captures the summated EPSPs and IPSPs.
  • ➤ Pyramidal Neurons: Major contributors to the signals detected by EEG.
  • ➤ Pyramidal Neurons:
  • ➤ Electrocorticography (ECOG): Involves placing electrodes directly on the cerebral cortex, not over the scalp, to measure electrical activity.
  • ➤ Electrocorticography (ECOG):

questions.text: Match the following EEG wave types with their respective frequency ranges and associated activities. Type of Wave Frequency Range (Hz) Activity During 1) Beta A) 8-13 i) Deep sleep 2) Alpha B) 14-30 ii) Relaxation, eyes closed 3) Theta C) 2-4 iii) Alert and active thinking 4) Delta D) 5-7 iv) Light sleep, emotional stress in adults

options.label: A
options.text: 1 - B - iii, 2 - A - ii, 3 - D - iv, 4 - C - i

options.label: B
options.text: 1 - C - i, 2 - B - iii, 3 - A - ii, 4 - D - iv

options.label: C
options.text: 1 - B - iii, 2 - D - iv, 3 - A - ii, 4 - C - i

options.label: D
options.text: 1 - A - ii, 2 - C - i, 3 - D - iv, 4 - B - iii

questions.correct_answer: A. 1 - B - iii, 2 - A - ii, 3 - D - iv, 4 - C - i
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Beta Waves: High frequency, associated with alertness and active thinking. Alpha Waves: Prominent during relaxation and eyes-closed states. Theta Waves: Associated with light sleep and emotional stress, not deep sleep.
  • ➤ Beta Waves: High frequency, associated with alertness and active thinking.
  • ➤ Alpha Waves: Prominent during relaxation and eyes-closed states.
  • ➤ Theta Waves: Associated with light sleep and emotional stress, not deep sleep.
  • ➤ Delta Waves: Lowest frequency, highest amplitude, associated with deep sleep.

Type of Wave

Frequency Range (Hz)

Activity During

Beta

14-30

Alert and active thinking

Alpha

8-13

Relaxation, eyes closed

Theta

5-7

Light sleep, emotional stress in adults

Delta

2-4

Deep sleep

questions.text: What type of waves are going to be seen if the patient is evaluated on EEG during deep sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Sleep spindles

options.label: B
options.text: K-Complexes

options.label: C
options.text: Theta waves

options.label: D
options.text: Delta waves

questions.explanation:
Stage of Sleep

Characteristics

Stage N1 Sleep

Light sleep, easy to wake up, characterised by theta waves. (Option C ruled out)

Stage N2 Sleep

Deeper than stage N1, the presence of sleep spindles and K-complexes, is still relatively easy to wake up. (Option A and B ruled out)

Stage N3 Sleep

Deepest sleep, Delta waves (low frequency and high amplitude), very difficult to wake up.

REM Sleep

Rapid eye movements, high brain activity, associated with dreaming, Beta wave pattern

questions.text: Which of the following statements about REM and NREM sleep is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: During NREM sleep, there is an increase in parasympathetic outflow, leading to lower heart rate and blood pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Muscle tone is completely lost during REM sleep, and the body is effectively paralyzed.

options.label: C
options.text: During deeper stages of NREM sleep, the subject is difficult to arouse by sensory stimuli.

options.label: D
options.text: During REM sleep, the subject is easily aroused by sensory stimuli.

questions.correct_answer: D. During REM sleep, the subject is easily aroused by sensory stimuli.
questions.explanation:
NREM Sleep

REM Sleep

Autonomic Outflow

Increased parasympathetic outflow, leading to lower heart rate and blood pressure (Option A ruled out)

Increased sympathetic outflow

Muscle Tone and Reflexes

Intact during NREM sleep

Complete loss of muscle tone (muscle atonia) during REM sleep (Option B ruled out)

Arousability

Difficult to arouse in deeper stages (Stages 3 and 4) (Option C ruled out)

More difficult to arouse compared to NREM sleep by sensory stimuli, but may awaken spontaneously.

Eye Movement

(EOG)

Absence of rapid eye movement

Presence of rapid eye movement

Brain Electrical Activity

Not associated with PGO (Ponto-Geniculo Occipital) spikes

Associated with PGO spikes

Dreaming Activity

Dreams uncertain; memorized if dreams occur

Vivid dreams; not memorized

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with severe insomnia, reporting that she has been unable to sleep for several days. Neurological examination reveals a lesion in the basal ganglia and adjacent anterior hypothalamus. Which of the following statements about the mechanisms of sleep is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The wake-promoting area is located in the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus and releases histamine.

options.label: B
options.text: The sleep-promoting area is located in the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus and releases GABA.

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased levels of adenosine at basal forebrain stimulate the sleep-promotion.

options.label: D
options.text: The awake state has increased NE, serotonin, and reduced levels of acetylcholine, while the opposite is true for the state of sleep

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreased levels of adenosine at basal forebrain stimulate the sleep-promotion.
questions.explanation:
Neurotransmitter

Awake State

REM State

NREM Sleep

Norepinephrine & Serotonin

High

Low

Low

Acetylcholine

Low (Option D ruled out)

High

Low

GABA & Histamine

Low GABA, High Histamine

High GABA, Low Histamine

High GABA, Low Histamine

questions.text: Match each sleep disorder with the correct stage of sleep in which it most commonly occurs Sleep Disorder Stage of Sleep a) Somnambulism 1) Stage 2 NREM b) Nocturnal enuresis 2) REM Sleep c) Narcolepsy 3) End of REM Sleep d) Sleep Paralysis 4) Stage 3 and 4 (NREM)
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B) a-4, b-1, c-2, d-3

Stage of Sleep

Sleep disorder

Stage 3 and 4 NREM

Somnambulism (Sleepwalking): Occurs during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, specifically stages 3 and 4.

Nocturnal enuresis: Occurs in stages 3/4. Common in childhood, due to the failure of neural regulation of micturition.

Stage 1 & 2 NREM

Sleep Talking (Somniloquy): This can occur in any stage of sleep but is most common in stages 1 and 2 of NREM sleep.

Bruxism (Teeth Grinding): Primarily occurs during stage 2 of NREM sleep.

The transition from stage 3 to 4 NREM

Night Terrors: Typically occur during the transition from stage 3 to stage 4 of NREM sleep. Unlike nightmares, individuals usually do not remember night terrors.

REM Sleep

Narcolepsy: Involves sudden onset of REM sleep. Individuals with narcolepsy often experience excessive daytime sleepiness, sudden muscle weakness (cataplexy), sleep paralysis, and hallucinations at the onset or end of sleep. The disorder is linked to a deficiency in the neurotransmitter orexin.

Nightmares: Occur during REM sleep and involve vivid, disturbing dreams that can cause fear and anxiety. Unlike night terrors, nightmares are often remembered in detail upon waking. They can be triggered by stress, anxiety, or trauma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with complaints of memory issues. He can recall general knowledge about the world, such as facts about historical events, but has difficulty remembering personal experiences, such as what he had for dinner last night or his activities from last weekend. Based on these symptoms, which of the following best describes the types of explicit memory affected in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Impaired semantic memory with intact episodic memory

options.label: B
options.text: Intact semantic memory with impaired episodic memory

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired procedural memory with intact working memory

options.label: D
options.text: Intact procedural memory with impaired working memory

questions.correct_answer: B. Intact semantic memory with impaired episodic memory

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who had a stroke several months ago reports that she is having difficulty with tasks she used to perform automatically. She struggles to remember how to ride her bicycle, a skill she previously performed with ease. She also mentions difficulty in learning new motor tasks. Based on these symptoms, which type of implicit memory is most likely affected in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Procedural memory

options.label: B
options.text: Priming

options.label: C
options.text: Associative learning

options.label: D
options.text: Semantic memory

questions.text: Which type of learning involves the process by which humans and animals learn to behave in such a way as to obtain rewards and avoid punishments?

options.label: A
options.text: Classical conditioning

options.label: B
options.text: Operant conditioning

options.label: C
options.text: Observational learning

options.label: D
options.text: Habituation

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the brain is responsible for working memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Prefrontal cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Neocortex

options.label: C
options.text: Ventral hippocampus

options.label: D
options.text: Amygdala

questions.text: Which of the following statements about synaptic plasticity and memory formation is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Long-term potentiation (LTP) primarily occurs at glutamatergic synapses in the hippocampus

options.label: B
options.text: Long-Term Depression (LTD) involves a significant influx of calcium into the postsynaptic neuron.

options.label: C
options.text: LTP leads to the phosphorylation of AMPA receptors, enhancing their activity and strengthening the synapse.

options.label: D
options.text: LTD is mediated by metabotropic glutamate receptors and involves dephosphorylation of AMPA receptors, leading to synaptic weakening.

questions.correct_answer: B. Long-Term Depression (LTD) involves a significant influx of calcium into the postsynaptic neuron.
